children.name: the natural world that people, animals, and plants live in
the environment b1
children.definition: the environment the air, water, and land where people, animals, and plants live, and the way all these things depend on each other so that life can continue:môi trường
examples: many modern farming methods are highly damaging to the environment.
young people between 18 and 30 tend to be much more concerned about the environment than the older generation.
ask your local mp what he or she intends to do to help protect the environment.

children.name: ecosystem x
children.definition: ecosystem the animals, plants etc that exist in a particular area or type of area and the way they all depend on each other in order to live, considered as a single separate part of the environment:hệ sinh thái
examples: the bay has a very complex and delicate ecosystem.
the rainforest is a self-supporting ecosystem.
a marine/forest/riverbank etc ecosystem
many species of burrowing insects are essential for maintaining a healthy soil ecosystem.

children.name: ecology x
children.definition: ecology/ɪˈkɒlədʒiǁɪˈkɑː-/  the way in which plants, animals, and the natural features of a place affect and depend on each other, or the scientific study of this:sinh thái, sinh thái học
examples: plans to build a new airfield could threaten the delicate ecology of the island.
she is giving a lecture about the natural history and ecology of the sea shore.
the oil spill caused terrible damage to the fragile ecologyofthe coast.
she hopes to study ecology at college.
ecologist[ c ] nhà sinh thái học
a person who studies the natural relationships between the air, land, water, animals, plants, etc.

children.name: to make sth dirty and dangerous
contaminate x
children.definition: contaminate/kənˈtæmɪneɪt, kənˈtæməneɪt/  to accidentally make a place or a substance dirty and dangerous by adding something to it, for example chemicals or bacteria:
examples: làm ô uế
▪ lead pipes can contaminate drinking water.
▪ the food was contaminated during the production process.
contamination/kənˌtæmɪˈneɪʃən, kənˌtæməˈneɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
▪ contamination of air, food and water
contaminateverb[ t ]làm bẩn,
to make something less pure or make it poisonous
_much of the coast has beencontaminated by nuclear waste.
_the food which had been contaminated was destroyed.
contaminationnoun[ u ]
_the water supply is being tested for contamination (= the presence of unwanted or dangerous substances) .

children.name: pollute b2
children.definition: pollute/pəˈluːt/  to make air, water, the ground etc dirty by putting chemicals or waste products into it, so that it is unsafe for use by people or animals:
examples: gây ô nhiễm
▪ an investigation revealed that the mine was polluting both the air and the groundwater.
▪ the company is charged with polluting the river mersey by allowing crude oil to enter the river.
pollute something with something
▪ the factory explosion, which polluted the surrounding area with dioxin, was reportedly caused by negligence.
polluteverb[ t ]làm ô nhiễm, làm nhơ bẩn (nước...)
to make an area or substance, usually air, water or earth, dirty or harmful to people, animals and plants, especially by adding harmful chemicals
_the fertilizers and pesticides used on many farms are polluting the water supply.
_we won't invest in any company that pollutes the environment.
_figurativemany americans complain that broadcasters pollute the airwaves with violence, sensationalism and sleaze.

children.name: recycle b1
children.definition: recycle/ˌriːˈsaɪkəl/  to put bottles, newspapers, cans etc through a process so that they can be used for making new glass products, paper etc:
examples: tái chế
▪ new techniques for recycling plastics are being introduced.
recyclable[adjective] có thể tái chế
▪ most cans are recyclable.
recycled[adjective] được tái chế
▪ all our envelopes are made from recycled paper.
recycling[adjective only before noun] tái chế
▪ a recycling bin
recycleverb[ t ]phục hồi; tái chế(sản phẩm tự nhiên)
to collect and treat rubbish in order to produce useful materials which can be used again
_the japanese recycle more than half their waste paper.
recyclableadjectivecó thể tái chế
able to be recycled

children.name: disposable c2
children.definition: disposable/dɪˈspəʊzəbəl/
examples: dùng một lần
▪ didn’t you know you can buy disposable contact lenses now?
giờ bạn có thể mua kính áp tròng dùng một lần được rồi đấy?
▪ a disposable toothbrush
bàn chải đánh răng dùng một lần
▪ disposable nappies
tã lót dùng một lần
disposableadjective dùng rồi vất đi; dùng một lần
describes a product that is intended to be thrown away after use
_disposable nappies
_a disposable camera
_daily disposable contact lenses

children.name: recycling b1
children.definition: recyclingnoun
examples: when paper, glass, plastic, etc. is put through a process so that it can be used again
_ways to encourage recycling
_a recycling centre
recycling/ ˌriːˈsaɪ.klɪŋ /noun[ u ]
b2 materials such as paper, glass, and plastic that you collect to be recycled:
we put out our recycling for pickup on tuesdays.
put this bottle with the recycling.

children.name: recycled b1
children.definition: recycledadjective tái chế
examples: having been used before and then processed so that it can form a new product
_this newspaper is made of recycledpaper.

children.name: population b2
children.definition: populationnoun quần thể
examples: all the people or animals of a particular type or group who live in one country, area or place
_there's been a 9% rise in the prison population (= the number of people in prison) .
_the dolphin population has been decimated by tuna fishing.

children.name: environmental b1
children.definition: environmental môi trường
examples: the explosion in the nuclear plant led to one of the most serious environmental catastrophes in history.
we want to stress the environmental benefits of a cheap, efficient public transport system.
environmental pollution
people are becoming far more aware of environmentalissues.
environmentally[adv] [b2]môi trường
the group claims that flying is one of the most environmentally damaging forms of travel.
car manufacturers worldwide are working to develop environmentally cleaner vehicles.

children.name: green b2
children.definition: green xanh
examples: green methods, products, practices etcare intended not to cause damage to the environment. green political groups are concerned with the protection of the environment:
a government committee is considering a proposal for a green energy policy
more money needs to be invested in developing greener fuel sources.
a conference attended by representatives of all the green parties of europe
a green campaigner/activist
the greenparty

children.name: ecological b2
children.definition: ecological relating to the way plants, animals, people, and the natural creatures of a particular place affect and depend upon each other - used especially by scientists or groups that try to protect the environment: sinh thái
examples: the government is to provide incentives for people to protect natural ecological assets such as forests.
there are warnings that the building of the dam will upset the ecological balance of the river basin.
ecologically[adv] [b2] thuộc về sinh thái
ecologically sound methods of pest elimination
it's an ecologicallyfriendly/sound(= not harmful) means of transport.

children.name: environmentally friendly b2
children.definition: environmentally friendly/ɪnˌvaɪərənˌmentəli ˈfrendli/  environmentally friendly products and methods do not damage the environment:
examples: thân thiện với môi trường
▪ many shoppers will buy environmentally friendly washing powders even if they are slightly more expensive.
▪ of course public transportation is more environmentally friendly than cars, but it needs to be efficient or people won’t use it.
▪ an environmentally friendly alternative to the aerosol spray
environmentally friendlyadjectivekhông cóhại chomôi trường; ít gây tác hại đến môi trường
not harmful to the environment
_environmentally-friendly washing powder

children.name: eco- x
children.definition: eco-/ˈiːkəʊ/  involved with or relating to the protection of the environment - used before some adjectives and nouns:
examples: sinh thái
▪ eco-friendly agriculture
▪ activists want the government to invest in low-impact eco-tourist facilities.
▪ officials see a role for sophisticated eco-technology to help eradicate pollution sweeping across the region.
eco-prefixmôi trường, sinh thái học
connected with the environment

children.name: renewable c1
children.definition: renewable/rɪˈnjuːəbəlǁrɪˈnuː-/  renewable forms ofenergy,fuel,materialsetc can be replaced naturally, so that they are never completely used up:
examples: tái tạo ( để tránh tình trạng khan hiếm )
▪ the ‘green’ housing community uses renewable energy sources such as solar power.
▪ the problem with fossil fuels is that they are not renewable.

children.name: sustainable c1
children.definition: sustainable/səˈsteɪnəbəl//  farming methods, methods of managing forests, hunting practices etc that are sustainable do not use up more land or trees or kill more animals than can be replaced, and therefore do not damage the environment: bền vững
examples: ▪ all wood used in our furniture comes with a certificate saying it comes from sustainable forests.
▪ traditional agricultural methods employed by the local people are highly sustainable.
sustainability/səˌsteɪnəˈbɪlɪti, səˌsteɪnəˈbɪləti/ [uncountable noun]
▪ the bill is an eu attempt to ensure the sustainability of cod fishing groups in the north sea.
sustainableadjective có thể chống đỡ được
causing little or no damage to the environment and therefore able to continue for a long time
_a large international meeting was held with the aim of promoting sustainabledevelopmentin all countries.

children.name: conservation b2
children.definition: conservation/ˌkɒnsəʳˈveɪʃənǁˌkɑːn-/  the practice of protecting animals, plants, forests etc, for example by officially not allowing building on the areas where they live or by not allowing them to be hunted:
examples: sự bảo tồn
▪ the group is mainly concerned with bird conservation in coastal areas.
conservation of sự bảo tồn của
▪ the conservation of several species of dolphin
conservation areaa place where plants, wild animals etc are officially protected : khu vực bảo tồn
▪ the flower now exists only in a small conservation area in essex.
conservationnoun[ u ]sự bảo tồn; sự bảo toàn
the protection of plants and animals, natural areas, and interesting and important structures and buildings,especially from the damaging effects of human activity
_wildlife conservation
_a conservation area
conservationc1noun[ u ]sự bảo tồn
carefully using valuable natural substances that exist in limited amounts in order to make certain that they will be available for as long a time as possible
_the conservation of coal/gas/oil reserves
_energyconservation reduces your fuel bills and helps the environment.

children.name: unsustainable c2
children.definition: unsustainableadjective không thể chống đỡ được
examples: causing damage to the environment by using more of something than can be replaced naturally
_unsustainable fishing methods

children.name: people who are concerned about the environment
environmental activist b1x
children.definition: environmental activist/group/ɪnˌvaɪərənmentl ˈæktvst, ˈgruːp/  a person or group who works to protect the environment, especially by trying to influence the government and large companies:
examples: nhà, nhóm hoạt động môi trường
▪ three environmental activists came to speak at the conference.

children.name: eco-warrior x
children.definition: eco-warrior/ˈiːkəʊˌ ˈwɒriəǁˌwɔː-/ informalsomeone who does extreme and often illegal things in order to protest against governments, companies etc who damage the environment:
examples: kẻ phá hoại sinh thái
▪ one of the young eco-warriors had to be pulled from a tree by police.

children.name: environmentalist c1
children.definition: environmentalistnounnhà môi trường học
examples: a person who is interested in or studies the environment and who tries to protect it from being damaged by human activities
environmentalismnoun[ u ]môi trường luận
an interest in or the study of the environment, in order to protect it from damage byhuman activities

children.name: environmental group b1a1
children.definition: environmental group đội bảo vệ môi trường
examples: a group of people whose aim is to protect the environment
▪ environmental groups and residents have united to protest against plans for a new shopping mall.

children.name: global warming b2
children.definition: global warming a general increase in the temperature of the world caused by harmful chemicals and gases from cars, factories etc entering the air: hiện tượng nóng lên toàn cầu
examples: scientists estimate that global warming could cause a six degree rise in temperatures by 2100.
one of the most devastating consequences of global warming could be the melting of the polar ice caps

children.name: greenhouse gases x
children.definition: greenhouse gases gases from cars, factories, machines etc that form a layer around the earth and keep the heat in. these are a cause of global warming: hiệu ứng nhà kính
examples: international controls are needed to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.
western countries are overwhelmingly responsible for current levels of greenhouse gases.

children.name: acid rain x
children.definition: acid rain rain that is harmful to trees and buildings because it contains pollution from factories, power stations etc:mưa axít
examples: typical symptoms of acid rain include deformed and dying trees, and trees with vastly reduced numbers of leaves.

children.name: climate change b2
children.definition: climate change changes in the weather across large areas of the world caused by damage to the natural environment, for example increases in temperature, more storms, or more or less rain: biến đổi khí hậu
examples: people will have to get used to more flooding and droughts as climate change becomes a reality.
an international conference on climate change

children.name: hole in the ozone layer u
children.definition: hole in the ozone layer a hole in the layer of natural gases around the earth that protects people, animals etc from damage from the sun. this is thought to be caused by harmful gases from cars, household products, factories etc entering the earth’s atmosphere:thủng tầng ô zôn
examples: the increase in the incidence of skin cancer is directly due to the hole in the ozone layer.

children.name: deforestation x
children.definition: deforestation when too many trees are cut down in an area, so that the environment is badly damaged:nạn phá rừng
examples: some parts of tropical america have seen over 70% deforestation.
the land is severely eroded as a result of widespread deforestation and intensive farming.

children.name: endangered species b2
children.definition: endangered species a type of animal, plant etc that might soon stop existing because of damage to the environment it lives in or because too many of them have been killed by humans:
examples: loài có nguy cơ tuyệt chủng
environmentalists say that the area includes the habitats of at least 20 endangered species.
although the tiger is an endangered species, it is still hunted in some areas.

children.name: population b2
children.definition: population all the people or animals of a particular type or group who live in one country, area or place : quần thể
examples: there's been a 9% rise in the prison population (= the number of people in prison) .
the dolphin population has been decimated by tuna fishing.

children.name: preservation c1
children.definition: preservationnoun sự gìn giữ, sự bảo quản, sự bảo tồn, sự duy trì
examples: when you keep something the same or prevent it from being damaged
wood/ building preservation
preservation of
eliot campaigned for the preservation of london’s churches.
we are working for the preservation of the environment.
the preservation of our cultural heritage
methods of food preservation

children.name: carbon footprint b2
children.definition: carbon footprint the amount of carbon dioxide that a person or organization produces by the things they do, used as a way of measuring the amount of harm they do to the environment : lượng khí thải nhà kính
examples: there are lots of ways you canreduceyourcarbon footprint.

children.name: emission c1
children.definition: emission when gas, heat, light, etc. is sent out: sự thải ra
examples: the green party have called for a substantial reduction in the emission of greenhouse gases by the uk.
britain agreed to cut emissions of nitrogen oxide from power stations.
emission[c usually p] [c1] a gas or other substance that is sent into the air : chất thải
carbon dioxide emissions
harmful emissions(= likely to cause harm to people or the environment )the law is designed to limit harmful emissions.
toxic emissions(= poisonous )by the end of the decade we could reduce toxic emissions by half.
noxious emissions(= harmful and poisonous )the air is a toxic cocktail of exhaust fumes and noxious emissions from nearby factories.
vehicle emissions(= from cars, lorries etc )california has introduced tough new standards for vehicle emissions.
industrial emissions(= from factories )the trees are being killed by acid rain and other industrial emissions.
sulphur dioxide/carbon dioxide/greenhouse gas etc emissionsthe treaty calls for a 30% reduction in sulphur dioxide emissions.
cut/reduce emissionsan agreement to cut emissions of gases which contribute to global warming
control/limit emissionsthe measures to control carbon dioxide emissions do not go far enough.

children.name: pollution b1
children.definition: pollution/pəˈluːʃən/  harmful chemicals, gases, or waste materials from factories, houses etc that enter the air, water, or land and kill or damage the things that live or grow there: sự ô nhiễm
examples: ▪ pollution levels in the area shot up as soon as the factory started operating.
▪ what pollution controls will the state authorities put in place?
air/marine/land etc pollution ô nhiễm không khí, ô nhiễm biển, ô nhiễm đất
▪ she says that transporting goods by rail instead of road would cut air pollution dramatically.
pollutant[countable noun] a chemical, gas etc that harms the environment: chất gây ô nhiễm
▪ carbon monoxide and other pollutants in traffic fumes
pollution/pəˈluːʃən/ [uncountable noun] the harmful effects on water, air, or land of chemicals and waste from factories, cars, modern farming methods etc:
chất ô nhiễm
▪ industrial pollution has killed much of the river’s wildlife.
▪ pollution from cars is the main cause of global warming.
▪ the convention, signed by the six states bordering the black sea, aims to reduce current pollution levels.
pollutionnoun[ u ]sự ô nhiễm
damage caused to water, air, etc. by harmful substances or waste
_air/water pollution
_the manifesto includes tough measures to tackle road congestion andenvironmentalpollution.
pollutantnoun[ c ]chất gây ô nhiễm (do xe cộ, động cơ.. thải ra)
a substance that pollutes
_sulphur dioxide is one of several pollutants that are released into the atmosphere by coal-fired power stations.
polluternoun[ c ]
a person or organization that pollutes

children.name: polluted b2
children.definition: polluted/pəˈluːtɪd, pəˈluːtəd/ waterorairthat is polluted has a lot of harmful waste or poisonous chemicals in it:
examples: ô nhiễm
▪ sayers said that if he’s elected his administration will make a priority of cleaning up the region’s polluted rivers.
▪ central london is the most polluted spot in britain.
polluted with/by
▪ large parts of the mediterranean are still polluted with toxic waste.
heavily polluted very badly polluted
▪ the air was heavily polluted with exhaust fumes.

children.name: contaminated x
children.definition: contaminated/kənˈtæmɪneɪtəd, kənˈtæməneɪtəd/ food,water, orlandthat is contaminated is not safe to use or be in because dangerous chemicals or bacteria have come into it:
examples: bị nhiễm bẩn
▪ contaminated drinking water
contaminated with/by
▪ several people became ill after eating hamburger meat contaminated with the e.coli bacteria.
heavilycontaminatedvery badly contaminated
▪ the soil around the plant is heavily contaminated.
contaminatedadjective bị ô nhiễm
_the infection was probably caused byswimming in contaminated water/water contaminatedwithsewage.
